events.summary: Juan II asks Alvaro de Luna for a briefing on world events. Alvaro reports Joan of Arc's execution in May 1431, the shifting momentum of the Hundred Years War toward France, Sigismund's coronation as King of Lombardy, the Hussites' devastating defeat of the fifth crusade at Domazlice, and the Ottoman advance under Murad II including the capture of Thessaloniki and the slow strangulation of Constantinople. Juan then dismisses Alvaro to carry out his previously assigned tasks and retires to pray.

Álvaro de Luna leans back in his chair, his expression thoughtful and grave. He considers your question for a moment before responding.

"Your Majesty asks the right questions. While we've been consumed by our own crusade—and rightly so—the world has not stood still." He rises and walks to the window, hands clasped behind his back.

"Let me start with the most dramatic news, because it affects the very nature of holy war itself. Joan of Arc was burned at the stake in Rouen on May 30th—not even half a year ago." He turns to face you. "A nineteen-year-old peasant girl who claimed God sent her visions to save France. She lifted the siege of Orléans in 1429, had Charles VII crowned at Reims, and turned the tide of the Hundred Years' War. The English captured her last year, tried her for heresy and witchcraft, and burned her."

He pauses significantly. "Think on that, Your Majesty. A girl who claimed divine guidance, who achieved military victories the French nobility could not, declared a heretic and witch by a church court controlled by the English. Now the French rally around her memory as a martyr. The English meant to discredit Charles VII by proving he was crowned by a heretic—instead they've created a saint in the making."

Álvaro returns to his seat. "France and England remain locked in their interminable war, but the momentum has shifted decisively to the French. The English hold only parts of Normandy and Gascony now. Their boy-king Henry VI—he's only ten years old—was hastily crowned in Paris last December, trying to counter Charles VII's legitimacy. But it's a losing fight. The Hundred Years' War is grinding toward an English defeat, though it may take another decade or two."

He pours himself wine. "The Holy Roman Empire is in its usual state of magnificent dysfunction. Sigismund finally received the Iron Crown of Lombardy in Milan this past November—just last month, in fact. He's been maneuvering for years to get Pope Eugenius to crown him Holy Roman Emperor proper, which should happen in the next year or two if the negotiations succeed. But his real power?" Álvaro shrugs. "The German princes do as they please. The electors tried to form a coalition against him in 1424. Sigismund is fighting on multiple fronts—the Hussites in Bohemia have been bleeding him dry for over a decade now."

"Which brings us to those damned Hussites," Álvaro continues, his voice darkening. "They've defeated five crusades sent against them. Sigismund lost catastrophically at Domažlice this past August—the very battle that sent Cardinal Cesarini fleeing to Basel. The Hussites are winning, Your Majesty. Militarily, theologically, politically. And now the Church is negotiating with them as equals at Basel. Think what message that sends: defy Rome, win enough battles, and the Church will eventually talk to you on your terms."

He leans forward. "As for the Ottomans—that may be the gravest threat of all, though it's farthest from us. Sultan Murad II has been systematically destroying what remains of Christian power in the East. Last year, 1430, he captured Thessalonika from the Venetians after a long siege. The Byzantine Empire?" Álvaro spreads his hands. "It barely exists. Emperor John VIII Palaeologos rules little more than Constantinople itself and a few scattered territories in Greece. The city is an island in an Ottoman sea."

"Murad has been at war constantly—against Venice, Hungary, Serbia, the various Turkish emirates in Anatolia. He's consolidating Ottoman power in the Balkans while the Christians fight among themselves. And Constantinople..." He shakes his head. "Its walls are still mighty, its position still defensible. But it's strangling. Cut off from resources, depopulated, impoverished. The Byzantines keep begging the West for help, offering church union in exchange for military aid. But the West is exhausted—France and England destroying each other, the Empire distracted by Hussites, Hungary threatened on all fronts."

Álvaro meets your eyes directly. "And this is why our crusade matters, Your Majesty. While Christianity is losing in the East—Hussites triumphant, Ottomans advancing, Constantinople dying—we have a chance for victory in the West. Granada is winnable. We have momentum, resources, papal backing. If we succeed where so many others are failing, it will be a beacon."

He refills his wine cup. "But it also means we cannot expect help from elsewhere. Sigismund is too busy with Bohemia. France and England are bleeding each other. Hungary is holding the line against the Ottomans but can spare nothing. Venice is licking its wounds from losing Thessalonika. We're on our own, which is both burden and blessing—we answer to no one but ourselves and the Pope."

"The Council of Basel complicates everything," he adds grimly. "Because if the conciliarists win and papal authority weakens, what becomes of papal crusading bulls? And if the Hussites secure a negotiated peace after defeating five crusades, what precedent does that set? These are dangerous times for the Church's authority, Your Majesty. Which makes your crusade—backed by proper papal authority, led by a legitimate Catholic monarch, aimed at a traditional enemy—all the more important as a demonstration that crusading still works when done right."

He pauses, studying you. "Does this answer your question about the state of the world? It's a grim picture, I know. But it also shows why we cannot afford to fail."

What is on your mind, Your Majesty?

The weight of the conversation with Álvaro settles over you: Joan of Arc burned as a heretic for claiming divine guidance, the Hussites defeating five crusades and forcing the Church to negotiate, Constantinople slowly strangling while the Ottomans advance, and the fundamental question at Basel about who truly governs the Church—Pope or councils?

events.summary: The following day, Juan proposes a bold tax reform for the upcoming Cortes: suspend all normal noble taxation and replace it with an 8% tax on actual revenue, with generous reimbursements for nobles supplying men-at-arms to the crusade. Alvaro explains how the current noble tax system actually works -- nobles pay fixed amounts set in ancient feudal grants, not percentages, meaning a duke paying 3,000 maravedis on grants assessed in 1311 actually earns 450,000 maravedis from those same lands today. The total noble tax gap is enormous: they pay 2-3 million maravedis instead of the 10-15 million they should contribute.

The next day I prepare to have council with Alvaro about tho upcoming Cortes.


I plan to unveil the following; I propose that for as long as the crusade lasts, all noble taxation will be suspended and replaced by an 8% tax on revenue with a substantial reimbursement if the nobles supply men at arms to the crusade effort. This eliminates the normal taxation entirely, but we get an actual tax on actual revenue at least. I want the cortes to confirm these taxes which will be more favorable to them, and convince the hardliners to also cooperate and open their books. Some have not been properly assessed this year and I want to make sure they are not being rewarded for this. How can we frame this so that most nobles who have paid correctly will rally to our side since it's unfair to them that they pay fair tax, but the l;arge noble estates do not.

1. Suspend all existing noble taxation for the duration of the crusade
2. Replace with an 8% revenue tax (this is significant - revenue vs. income/profit)
3. Offer substantial reimbursements if nobles supply men-at-arms to the crusade
4. This creates an incentive structure that could actually lower their burden if they contribute militarily
5. The goal is to get proper assessment of noble estates that have been evading or underreporting
6. Frame it so compliant nobles see it as fair, making them allies against the large estates that don't pay properly

This is politically sophisticated. Juan is trying to:
- Create a coalition of smaller/compliant nobles against large estate holders
- Use the crusade as justification for temporary reform
- Make it seem favorable (tax elimination + replacement with seemingly lower burden)
- Actually get proper accounting from estates that have been evading
- Incentivize military contribution

Álvaro would have complex thoughts on this:
- Politically clever framing
- Could work to split noble opposition
- Revenue tax vs. income tax matters a lot (revenue is gross, income is net)
- 8% on revenue could be VERY high for some operations with thin margins
- Need to be careful about how "revenue" is defined
- The reimbursement structure needs careful calibration
- Large estates that have avoided proper assessment will fight hard
- Need to identify which nobles are compliant to make them allies
- Cortes politics requires careful vote counting
- This is essentially using the crusade to achieve financial reform that's been needed

Let me have Álvaro engage with this thoughtfully, pointing out strengths, weaknesses, and how to frame it politically. He should be impressed by the political sophistication but also point out potential pitfalls.

The next morning, you summon Álvaro de Luna to your private council chamber. He arrives promptly, carrying ledgers and documents—clearly he's been working through the night on the tasks you assigned.

"Your Majesty," he greets you, setting down his materials. "I have drafts of the indulgence guidance and the letters to the commanders ready for your review. Archbishop García has agreed to convene the Toledo council—summons will go out within three days."

You gesture for him to sit. "Excellent work, Álvaro. But this morning I want to discuss the upcoming Cortes. I have been thinking about our taxation problem—specifically, the large estates that avoid proper assessment while smaller nobles pay honestly."

His eyes sharpen with interest. "Go on."

You lay out your proposal: suspending all normal noble taxation for the crusade's duration, replacing it with an 8% tax on revenue, with substantial reimbursements for nobles who supply men-at-arms to the effort.

Álvaro listens intently, his expression shifting from curiosity to calculation to something approaching admiration. When you finish, he leans back in his chair.

"Your Majesty..." He pauses, choosing his words carefully. "This is remarkably sophisticated. The political framing alone—presenting it as tax elimination rather than reform—that's inspired. And using the crusade as justification creates a time-limited structure that makes it less threatening."

He stands and begins pacing, as he does when working through complex problems.

"Let me think through the mechanics and the politics," he says. "First, the strengths of your proposal:

The Political Framing is Excellent: You're not increasing taxes, you're suspending them and replacing them with something that sounds simpler and more favorable. The word 'suspension' implies temporary, tied to the crusade. That makes it palatable."

He ticks off points on his fingers. "The military reimbursement is clever—it transforms a tax into an investment. A noble who supplies twenty men-at-arms might actually pay less than under the old system, while we get troops. Those who contribute to the crusade benefit; those who don't, pay more. That's incentive alignment."

"Most importantly," Álvaro continues, "you're creating a coalition of the compliant against the evasive. The Mendozas, the Enríquez, houses that have paid honestly—they'll see this as fair. 'Why should we pay our full assessment while the great estates hide their wealth?' You turn them into your advocates."

He pauses at the window. "But Your Majesty, there are significant complications we must address:

First: The 8% Revenue Tax Structure

"Revenue versus income matters enormously," Álvaro says seriously. "Revenue is gross receipts—everything that comes in before expenses. Income is what remains after costs. An 8% tax on revenue could be devastating for some operations."

He pulls out a ledger to illustrate. "Consider a merchant noble who trades in grain. His revenue might be 10,000 maravedís annually. But his costs—purchasing grain, transport, warehousing, spoilage, labor—might be 9,000 maravedís. His actual profit is only 1,000. Under the old system, he paid tax on that 1,000. Under your proposal, he pays 800 maravedís—80% of his entire profit—on the gross revenue."

"Conversely," he continues, "a great estate with rental income has almost no costs. Their revenue IS nearly their income. An 8% tax on rents is actually quite favorable compared to what they should pay."

"So we have a problem: Your tax might hit the wrong people—merchants, smaller landholders with expenses—while being lenient on the vast estates with pure rental income that are the real evaders."

Second: Defining 'Revenue' Will Be a Battle

"Every noble will fight about what counts as revenue," Álvaro warns. "Do we count:

Gross rents before maintenance costs?

Agricultural yields before seed and labor?

Trade receipts before goods purchased?

Feudal dues and fees?

Income from offices and appointments?

Marriage portions and inheritances?"

He spreads his hands. "The moment you say 'revenue,' you've opened a thousand definitional disputes. We need crystal-clear rules, or the Cortes will tear this apart arguing about what counts."

Third: The Assessment Problem

"Your insight is correct—some large estates have never been properly assessed. But here's the challenge: They've avoided assessment because they're powerful. The Álvaro de Estúñiga holdings, the Duke of Arévalo's estates, certain branches of the de la Cerda family—these aren't evading assessment by accident. They're evading it because they have the power to refuse."

Álvaro meets your eyes. "Your proposal forces them to open their books. That's good. But they will fight viciously because those books contain secrets—not just wealth, but how they acquired it. Rents extracted illegally. Lands seized during civil wars. Revenues from 'tolls' that are basically highway robbery with legal pretense."

"They will see this as an existential threat."

Fourth: The Reimbursement Calculation

"The military reimbursement must be calibrated perfectly," Álvaro says. "Too generous, and we lose revenue we desperately need. Too stingy, and there's no incentive to contribute troops."

He does quick calculations. "A mounted knight costs roughly 3,000 maravedís to equip and maintain for a campaign season. If we reimburse the full 3,000, nobles break even. If we reimburse 4,000, they profit by supplying troops—which creates wrong incentives. If we reimburse 2,000, they still pay 1,000 per knight out of pocket after the tax reduction."

"We need to find the sweet spot where:

Contributing troops is clearly beneficial

But not so beneficial that nobles send us garbage troops just to collect reimbursement

And we still net positive revenue after reimbursements"

Now, How to Frame This for Political Success:

Álvaro returns to his seat, leaning forward intently.

"Your instinct to split the nobles is correct. Here's how we make it work:

Step One: Identify the Coalition of the Compliant

"Before the Cortes, we need to know exactly who's paid honestly and who hasn't. I'll have the treasury review every assessment from the past three years. We'll create two lists:

List A: The Compliant (paid fair assessments, opened books, cooperated)
List B: The Evaders (contested assessments, refused review, paid suspiciously little)

"Then we approach List A nobles privately before the Cortes. We say: 'His Majesty recognizes your faithful payment. This reform protects you by ensuring everyone pays fairly. We need your support to stop the evaders from continuing to cheat.'

"Make them stakeholders in reform, not victims of it."

Step Two: Frame It As Crusade Patriotism

"The message is: 'The King asks nothing for himself. Every maravedi goes to holy war against Granada. Those who contribute troops pay even less. Those who refuse to open their books reveal they care more about hiding wealth than defeating the infidel.'

"We're not attacking noble privilege. We're questioning the patriotism of anyone who won't support the crusade."

Step Three: Offer The Escape Hatch

"The military reimbursement must be generous enough that most nobles will take it. A noble who supplies men-at-arms should pay noticeably less than one who doesn't. This creates two paths:

Path A: Pay the 8% tax, supply troops, get substantial reimbursement, end up paying less than under old system while serving the crusade.

Path B: Pay the 8% tax, supply no troops, pay more than you would under Path A, and look unpatriotic.

"Most nobles will take Path A. The ones who take Path B reveal themselves as the problem."

Step Four: The 'Sunset Clause' Reassurance

"Emphasize repeatedly: This is for the crusade duration only. When the crusade ends, we'll return to normal taxation (with proper assessments). This prevents panic about permanent change.

"Of course," Álvaro adds with a slight smile, "if the crusade lasts several years and everyone gets used to the new system... well, that's a conversation for later."

Step Five: Make The Math Public

"We should present clear examples in the Cortes:

Example 1: 'Count Rodrigo has estates yielding 50,000 maravedís in rent. Under old system: 8,000 maravedís tax. Under new system: 4,000 maravedís tax, plus he supplies ten knights worth 2,000 maravedís reimbursement each = 20,000 back. Net cost: -16,000 maravedís. He profits by serving the crusade.'

(Note: These numbers are illustrative, we'd need to adjust them.)

"Show nobles they can come out ahead by participating."

The Votes You Need:

Álvaro pulls out a list. "The Cortes requires majority approval, but practical success requires broad consensus. You need:

Certain Votes (Will Support):

The compliant nobles (List A)

Smaller estates (will benefit from removal of fixed assessments)

Crusade enthusiasts (already committed)

Church representatives (supporting papal crusade)

Crown loyalists (Mendozas, Enríquez core supporters)

Persuadable Votes (Could Go Either Way):

Mid-sized estates (depends on their specific situation)

Nobles who want to avoid military service (might prefer paying)

Practical merchants (depends on revenue vs. income calculation)

Certain Opposition (Will Fight):

Large estates that have evaded assessment (Estúñiga faction, certain de la Cerdas)

Nobles with complex, hard-to-assess holdings

Those philosophically opposed to any taxation reform

"You probably have 40% solid support, 30% persuadable, 30% opposition. You need to win most of the middle 30%."

My Recommendations for Adjustments:

Álvaro spreads his hands. "Your Majesty's concept is sound, but I suggest these refinements:

One: Tiered Revenue Tax Instead of Flat 8%

"Consider:

6% on first 20,000 maravedís revenue

8% on revenue above 20,000

10% on revenue above 100,000

"This protects smaller estates while hitting the great estates harder. Politically, small nobles will love it. Great estates can't complain without admitting they're wealthy."

Two: Very Clear Revenue Definitions

"We need a schedule: 'Revenue means:

Agricultural: Gross harvest value minus seed costs

Rents: Gross rents minus essential maintenance

Commercial: Gross receipts minus cost of goods sold

Feudal dues: Face value

Etc.'

"Argue about definitions before the Cortes, not during."

Three: Generous Military Reimbursement

"Make the reimbursement obviously worthwhile. If a knight costs 3,000 to field, reimburse 3,500. Noble pays 500 out of pocket but gets propaganda value of 'serving the crusade.' We're still ahead because:

We get troops we'd otherwise have to hire

It comes from nobles who would otherwise pay tax

Net cost to treasury is lower than hiring mercenaries"

Four: Automatic Audit Trigger

"Any estate that reports revenue below X threshold automatically gets audited. This stops obviously false reporting without requiring us to audit everyone."

Five: Reward for Early Compliance

"Nobles who open their books fully before the Cortes begins get a 1% tax reduction. This rewards cooperation and gives us information advantage going in."

Álvaro finishes and sits back. "Your Majesty, the core concept is brilliant—politically sophisticated, practically defensible, and it uses the crusade to achieve needed reform. With these adjustments, I believe we can win the Cortes vote.

"But make no mistake: this will be a fight. The great estates know that opening their books is the beginning of the end of their tax advantages. They'll spend heavily, trade favors, and possibly threaten to withhold military support.

"The question is: Are you prepared for that battle? Because once we propose this in Cortes, there's no backing down without looking weak."

He meets your eyes seriously. "And if we win this fight, Your Majesty... you'll have fundamentally reformed Castilian taxation using the crusade as leverage. That's not just clever. That's statesmanship."

What are your thoughts on Álvaro's analysis and recommendations?

   - Refusing to pay taxes you DO legally owe (breach of contract, possibly rebellion)
   - Taking up arms against the king (open rebellion/treason)

4. **Practical Reality**: Medieval kings often couldn't just "send the army" because:
   - The army WAS mostly composed of noble levies
   - You can't use a noble's own men to attack him
   - You'd need loyal nobles/crown forces to attack disloyal ones
   - Could trigger civil war

   - Could declare them in breach of feudal contract
   - Could declare them in defiance of papal authority (more serious)
   - Could seize their lands for breach of obligation
   - But enforcement requires actual military power
